newsitem.title: ARGENTINA: Argentine bank buyouts show confidence-Rodriguez.
newsitem.headline: Argentine bank buyouts show confidence-Rodriguez.

text.p: The Argentine Economy Ministry's chief Advisor Carlos Rodriguez said buyouts of local banks by foreign institutions were "an enormous vote of confidence," the La Nacion daily reported Tuesday.
"This is an enormous sign of confidence in the economic model, since we are talking about direct investments, not short term ones," Rodriguez told La Nacion in an interview.
Last week banking giant HSBC Holdings Plc said it will buy all of the local Roberts Group, including Banco Roberts, for between $600 million and $688 million.
Days before, Spain's Banco Santander SA said it would buy 35.06 percent of Banco Rio for $594 million, giving it voting control.
A couple of weeks earlier, Spain's Banco Bilbao Viscaya SA's Banco Frances bought 71.8 percent of retail bank Banco de Credito Argentino.
"Additionally, this is a very important contribution to stability and strengthening of the financial system," Rodriguez added.
Opposition political parties have criticized the passage of so many large banks into the hands of foreign owners.
But Rodriguez dismissed such talk, saying "this does not mean a loss of national capital, but that Argentina is being integrated into world markets, since these are commercial operations."
Rodriguez admitted that foreign investors may be getting mixed signals from Argentina following the recent spate of social protests.

"Nevertheless, even though our message to the rest of the world may be confusing, it is obvious that the macroeconomic information prevails, because investors keep coming, and they are doing so at an unexpected rate," Rodriguez said.
